main event: On May 24, 1954, near Richmond, Indiana, an Air Force Major flying a photographic mapping mission observed and photographed a large, high-intensity light moving below his aircraft. The light traveled a distance of six miles over the ground at a speed twice that of the aircraft.
interesting points: The observed light traveled at a speed twice that of the aircraft and covered a distance of six miles over the ground.
Extensive studies and investigations were conducted, including examining the ground under the path taken by the aircraft and the object, but no material object was found.
The data was submitted to a panel of scientists and specialists, including astronomers, meteorologists, and a physicist.
The sighting was concluded to be a very rare aerial phenomena caused by the reflection of the sun's rays upon an ice-crystal platelet formation.
A significant case that led to a complete investigation, which included analysis of photographs and ground characteristics.
sighted object: large, high-intensity light moving below the aircraft
witnesses: Air Force Major on a photographic mapping mission
